TextEquiv.Unicode: they being dispersed and scattered a
broad, did sometime come unto the holy
citie of Jerusalem. There were dwel
ling at lerusalem certaine lewes reli
ious men, of all nations that are un
der heaven. And that also which saint
Paule reciteth of him selfe confirmeth
the same, that being born free in the ci
tie of Tharsus, he travelled to Jerusa
lem unto Gamaliels feete, that is to
say, to the intent to heare the instructi
on, and to be a scholer under Gamaliel,
So likewise we read that at Jerusa
lem there were Colledges or Synago
gues of the Livertines, Cyrenians, A
lerandrines, Cilicians, and Asians.
This use of scholes continued until
Christes time, yea, and after his as
cension into the heavens, almost until
the destruction of the citie, although in
the mean time it may appeare to have
beene sundrie times depraved.
Christ also the sonne of God, our
king and high Bishoppe, he himelfe
instituted the most famous schole of al
other, calling thereunto the twelve A
postles, and the seventie disciples, cho
sen men, I say, to the number of foure
score and two. Pea, the Apostles them
selves drew unto them very many dis
ciples, and first of all saint Paul the
most chosen instrument of God to con
vert the Gentiles, is read to have had
in his companie, Sopater of Berrhee,
Luke of Antioch, Marke of Jerusalem,
Barnabas, Eylua or bylvanus, Caius
and Timothie, Aristarchus and Secun
dus, Tychicus and Prophimus, Fitus
and Linus, Erescens and Epaphras, Ar
chippus and Philemon, Epaphroditus
and Artemas, and many other
He hath also commended most dili
gently unto good men, the studious, and
the ministers of the Churches, exhor
ting all men unto liberalitie, that they
may want nothing. Aud writing unto

they being dispersed and scattered a broad, did sometime come unto the holy citie of Jerusalem. There were dwel ling at lerusalem certaine lewes reli ious men, of all nations that are un der heaven. And that also which saint Paule reciteth of him selfe confirmeth the same, that being born free in the ci tie of Tharsus, he travelled to Jerusa lem unto Gamaliels feete, that is to say, to the intent to heare the instructi on, and to be a scholer under Gamaliel, So likewise we read that at Jerusa lem there were Colledges or Synago gues of the Livertines, Cyrenians, A lerandrines, Cilicians, and Asians. This use of scholes continued until Christes time, yea, and after his as cension into the heavens, almost until the destruction of the citie, although in the mean time it may appeare to have beene sundrie times depraved. Christ also the sonne of God, our king and high Bishoppe, he himelfe instituted the most famous schole of al other, calling thereunto the twelve A postles, and the seventie disciples, cho sen men, I say, to the number of foure score and two. Pea, the Apostles them selves drew unto them very many dis ciples, and first of all saint Paul the most chosen instrument of God to con vert the Gentiles, is read to have had in his companie, Sopater of Berrhee, Luke of Antioch, Marke of Jerusalem, Barnabas, Eylua or bylvanus, Caius and Timothie, Aristarchus and Secun dus, Tychicus and Prophimus, Fitus and Linus, Erescens and Epaphras, Ar chippus and Philemon, Epaphroditus and Artemas, and many other He hath also commended most dili gently unto good men, the studious, and the ministers of the Churches, exhor ting all men unto liberalitie, that they may want nothing. Aud writing unto
Iitus: Bring diligentlye sayeth hee,
Zenas the Lawyer and Apollo, upon
their waye, that they may want no
thing.
Moreover it may bee gathered by
plaine and manifest proofes out of the
thirteenth chapter of the Actes, that
there was a verie famous and that an
Apostolique schoole at Antioch in Sy
ria. Eusebius also of Cesarea aboun
dantly witnesseth what noble schooles
were at Alerandria in Egypt, and in
other renoumed churches. And wee
have also declared the same more at
large, when time serued, in a booke
which we have written of the institu
tion of Bishops.
But in processe of time when all
things appertaining to the Church be
ganne to decline to the worsse, Ecclesi
asticall schooles also degenerated into
Abbaies, or into Colledges of Canons
and Monkes.
But of all these thinges whereof
wee have spoken, I thinke it not un
knowen unto any man, that schooles
doe printipally belong to the preser
vation of the Church, and the main
tenance of the holie ministerie, in
which schooles good artes might be ex
ercised, verie profitable for the fur
theraunce of the studie of the holie
Scriptures: of which forte chiefest of
all are the Cludies and knowledge of
holy tongues, of Logick, naturall Phi
losophie, and the Mathematicks, and
these moderately knowen, and directed
unto the certaine scope and ende of
Godlinesse. For a man may some
time finde wittes worne and wared
olde in diverfe Artes and disciplines,
howbeit not once medling or inured
with holy exercises and studies. But
I would to God that the wicked be
ing too much glutted with prophane
studie, would also leave to contemne

Iitus: Bring diligentlye sayeth hee, Zenas the Lawyer and Apollo, upon their waye, that they may want no thing. Moreover it may bee gathered by plaine and manifest proofes out of the thirteenth chapter of the Actes, that there was a verie famous and that an Apostolique schoole at Antioch in Sy ria. Eusebius also of Cesarea aboun dantly witnesseth what noble schooles were at Alerandria in Egypt, and in other renoumed churches. And wee have also declared the same more at large, when time serued, in a booke which we have written of the institu tion of Bishops. But in processe of time when all things appertaining to the Church be ganne to decline to the worsse, Ecclesi asticall schooles also degenerated into Abbaies, or into Colledges of Canons and Monkes. But of all these thinges whereof wee have spoken, I thinke it not un knowen unto any man, that schooles doe printipally belong to the preser vation of the Church, and the main tenance of the holie ministerie, in which schooles good artes might be ex ercised, verie profitable for the fur theraunce of the studie of the holie Scriptures: of which forte chiefest of all are the Cludies and knowledge of holy tongues, of Logick, naturall Phi losophie, and the Mathematicks, and these moderately knowen, and directed unto the certaine scope and ende of Godlinesse. For a man may some time finde wittes worne and wared olde in diverfe Artes and disciplines, howbeit not once medling or inured with holy exercises and studies. But I would to God that the wicked be ing too much glutted with prophane studie, would also leave to contemne
